page.title: 01Introduction: the Deverills
page.content: This area is part of what is known as {the Deverill Valley.}It includes three of five villages bearing the name Deverill,{Longbridge, Hill and Brixton {Deverill.}At the time of the{Domesday {Book}there were nine 'Devral 'villages They took their name from the Deverill stream which feeds the head-waters of the{River Wylye.}They lie along its lovely valley as the river meanders through a landscape of rounded chalk hills. The chalk upland reaches 845 feet at{Cold Kitchen Hill}and the land is nowhere below 400 feet.It is still an almost purely agricultural area of cereal crops and grass, sheep and cattle.Though the old sluice-gates are no longer opened to flood the water meadows in the Spring, the Trout Farm and Cress Farm still reflect the importance of water in a valley whose name derives from a Celtic stream name
